text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A small wooden block has a cylindrical hole drilled through it from the front to the back.
The block measures 3cm × 3cm × 3cm, and the cylindrical hole has a diameter of 1cm.
The center of the hole is positioned exactly in the middle of the front face.
Draw or describe the top view, front view, and side view of this object in orthographic projection.

In which view(s) will the hole be visible as a complete circle? In which view(s) will the hole appear as a rectangle? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I've got this problem here about a wooden block with a cylindrical hole drilled through it.
The block is a cube, 3 cm by 3 cm by 3 cm.
The hole is cylindrical with a diameter of 1 cm, and the center of the hole is exactly in the middle of the front face.
I need to figure out what the top, front, and side views look like in orthographic projection.
Then, I have to determine in which views the hole appears as a complete circle and in which it appears as a rectangle.
First, let me visualize the cube.
Since it's a 3x3x3 cube, all edges are 3 cm long.
The hole is drilled from the front to the back, so it's along the depth of the cube.
The diameter of the hole is 1 cm, so the radius is 0.5 cm.
The center of the hole is in the middle of the front face, which means it's exactly at the center point of the front face.
Now, orthographic projection is a type of axonometric projection where the object is rotated so that its faces are parallel to the projection plane.
In this case, we're looking at the top, front, and side views.
Each view will show the outline of the cube and the hole.
Starting with the top view.
The top view looks straight down onto the cube.
Since the hole is drilled from front to back, in the top view, the hole will appear as a circle because we're looking at it from above, and the circular cross-section is visible.
The diameter is 1 cm, so the circle will have a diameter of 1 cm.
The center of this circle will be at the center of the cube's top face.
Next, the front view.
The front view looks directly at the front face of the cube.
The hole is centered on this front face, so in the front view, the hole will also appear as a circle.
The same diameter of 1 cm applies here, and the circle is centered at the middle of the front face.
Now, the side view.
The side view looks at the cube from one of its side faces, say the right or left face.
In this view, the hole is drilled through the cube from front to back, but the side view is perpendicular to the front face.
Since the hole is cylindrical, when viewed from the side, the hole will appear as a rectangle.
The height of this rectangle will be the diameter of the hole, which is 1 cm, and the width will be the depth of the hole, which is the same as the edge of the cube, so 3 cm.
But wait, that doesn't sound right.
Let me think again.
Actually, in the side view, we're looking at the depth of the cube.
The hole is drilled through the entire depth, which is 3 cm.
However, the hole is only 1 cm in diameter.
So, the side view would show the hole as a rectangle because we're looking at the length of the hole along the depth of the cube.
The height of this rectangle would be the diameter of the hole (1 cm), and the width would be the depth of the hole (3 cm).
So, the rectangle is 1 cm by 3 cm.
Wait, but I'm a bit confused.
In the side view, the hole is a cylinder, so when viewed from the side, it's a rectangle because we're seeing the height and depth.
The height is 1 cm (diameter) and the depth is 3 cm.
So, yes, the side view will show the hole as a rectangle.
So, putting it all together: the top view shows a circle, the front view shows a circle, and the side view shows a rectangle.
I think that makes sense.
The top and front views are looking at the circular cross-sections of the hole, while the side view is looking along the length of the hole, making it appear as a rectangle.

</think>

The top view shows a circle with a diameter of 1 cm centered on the top face.
The front view also shows a circle of the same size centered on the front face.
The side view shows a rectangle measuring 1 cm (height) by 3 cm (width), aligned with the center of the cube.

- **Top View**: Circle
- **Front View**: Circle
- **Side View**: Rectangle

In the top and front views, the hole appears as a complete circle, while in the side view, it appears as a rectangle.
